resources.string:
零 
  rei = 0 

  いち 
  ichi = 1 

  に 
  ni = 2 

  さん  san = 3 

  し、よん 
  shi, yon = 4 

  ご 
  go = 5 

  ろく 
  roku = 6 

  しち、なな 
  shichi, nana = 7 

  はち 
  hachi = 8 

  く、きゅう 
  ku, kyuu = 9 

  じゅう
  juu = 10 

 Adding 1 “ichi” (いち) as a suffix to 10 “juu” (じゅう), and you will get 11 じゅういち(juu-ichi). So, counting from 10 to 20 in Japanese just means repeating this same pattern until number 19.

  じゅういち
  Jū-ichi = 11 

  じゅうに 
  Jū-ni = 12 

  じゅうさん 
  Jū-san = 13 

  じゅうよん、じゅうし 
  Jū-yon, jū-shi = 14

  じゅうご 
  Jū-go = 15

  じゅうろく 
  Jū-roku = 16

  じゅうしち、じゅうなな
  Jū-shichi, jū-nana = 17

  じゅうはち 
  Jū-hachi = 18

  じゅうきゅう 
  Jū-kyū = 19

  にじゅう 
  Ni-jū = 20

  100 is pronounced as “hyaku” in Japanese 

  ひゃくいち 
  hyaku-ichi = 101

  ひゃくよんじゅうご 
  hyaku-yon-ju go = 145

  ひゃくきゅうじゅうきゅう 
  hyaku-kyu-ju kyu = 199

おはようございます 
  Ohayou-gozaimasu = Good morning 

  こんにちは 
  Kon’nichiwa = Hello 

  こんばんは 
  Konbanwa = Good evening/hello (during evening/night) 

  ありがとうございます  Arigatou gozaimasu = Thank you 

  おやすみなさい 
  Oyasumi nasai = Good night 

  さようなら 
  Sayōnara = if it is so, farewell 

  ごきげんよう 
  gokigenyō = farewell 

  行ってきます 
  Ittekimasu = I’ll go and come back 

  行ってらしゃい 
  itterasshai = please go and come back 

  ただいま 
  Tadaima = I have come back now 

  おかえり
  okaeri = welcome back 

  もしもし
  Moshi moshi = Hello (when answering phone) 

  お疲れ様です 
  Otsukaresama desu = Thank you for your hard work 

  ようこそ 
  Yōkoso = Welcome 

  いらっしゃいませ 
  irasshaimase = Welcome (service staff greeting)
